news_header: Germany has reintroduced border controls at all its borders, preventing 30,000 people from entering the country. This move is part of a broader trend among EU countries to tighten internal border checks amidst concerns over illegal immigration.
news_text: Germany has implemented border controls across all its borders, resulting in the prevention of 30,000 individuals from entering the country. This decision follows a similar trend among eight EU countries that are currently enforcing passport checks at internal borders. The reintroduction of these controls was accelerated by an incident involving a Syrian asylum seeker. While some travelers express understanding and support for the checks, concerns about the impact on freedom of movement within the Schengen area persist. The German government aims to manage migration effectively, especially in light of rising popularity for far-right parties. The EU is also considering reforms to improve control at external borders, with illegal crossings reportedly down by 42% compared to the previous year. However, asylum applications remain high, and attitudes towards immigration are becoming more stringent across Europe.
